physical_appearance: This is a batik sarong. The middle of the sarong features a maroon panel, with large bouquets of flowers and butterflies. The panels are segmented by borders of floral bouquet motifs. The other panels have lime green with white dots as a background. There is a signature on the top left of the batik sarong.
sgcool_label_text: Butterflies flutter amidst the large bouquet of flowers on the maroon, broad vertical panel (kepala) of this sarong.  The fluid expression of the buketan (or ‘bouquet’) motif is echoed in the borders that separate the kepala from the lime green “body” (badan) of the sarong.  The lime green background is filled with white dots known as tanahan motifs.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Kok Sing (1896-1966), the second in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her later batik designs attest to her virtuosity in technique and inventive colour palette.  Her repertoire of tiny isen-isen motifs (filler motifs within the outlines of the key motifs) in particular, exudes a strong sense of artistic individuality, possibly informed by modernist designs on European printed cloths.  Her treatment of floral bouquets is also charactertistic of the undulating and curving lines of the Art Noveau style that was introduced in the northern coast of Java by the Europeans.  This piece is signed “Nj Oey Kok Sing”.
subject_terms_2: Batik Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Motifs
